comments.raw_text:
Currently when the user click's "stop" in the slow-script dialog we simply throw an exception. I'm not even sure if it's an uncatchable one.

However if the slow script was triggered as a result from an event handler, or timeout, we might call right back into it.

This both means that a malicious page could DoS the user by continuously call into slow scripts, and a well-meaning web developer could easily do the same on accident.

Ideally we should simply disable all scripts in the page once the user has killed a script using the slow-script dialog.

Not sure if we should close it since there might be data that the user could copy out of it as to prevent dataloss.

> Not sure if we should close it

I don't think we should; a misbehaving ad script should not be able to stop the user from reading an article.

Disabling the nsIScriptContext would make some sense.  Just have to make sure to reenable on navigation.
